creator: murraymc

content:
murraymc said
Optus support insisted - repeatedly - that they did not know the correct config for T'bird since some changes. Will see if that advice is current and still works. Thanks for your assistance.

A mail client; such as Thunderbird,Outlook or even others such as the venerable Eudora can only connect to the sever using the settings configured and published by the mail administrator for the server you are connecting to. Anything else you are told by the script readers at OPTUS is rubbish. They set the connection parameters and ALL mail clients have to use them, not just Thunderbird.

There are some serious irregularities with Optus, they specify ports to use currently that the rest of the world abandoned as obsolete some 25 years ago. That was about the time I closed my Optus account, than would have been 1997. But Optus publish those setting as the correct ones, selected and promoted by them.

SO please do check your settings against those Optus publish. Paying particular attention to the type of account you have.

You need to also be aware that many antivirus programs other than Windows Defender scan email by hacking the encryption certificates used. This requires a manual self signed certificate to be added to Thunderbird to allow this hacking to occur. It is common in my experience that those with Optus also tend to use Norton product and these are well known for having issues with Certificates. The bluemail email program has a support document advising how to change Avast and Norton to fix that issue. https://bluemail.me/help/windows-antivirus/
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The message is indicating that you do not have your incoming server defined according to their requirements. Possibly, if you post a screenshot of your incoming server settings pane, some suggestions will come forth,

content:
Prova a fare queste operazioni di manutenzione:

  1. Fare un backup integrale del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compattare le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavviare Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, ricostruire l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavviare Thunderbird
  6. Se il problema non si è ancora risolto: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella]

content:
As enclosed, S/MIME information says that certificate is untrusted, which is not really accurate.

This has got nothing to do with cert validity. Thunderbird is verifying the entire certificate chain. If that fails you get the 'untrusted certificate' error. It does fail because you either didn't import an intermediate and/or root CA cert, or a cert you imported is not trusted for email.
creator: christ1

content:
That is the whole point of my support request that the information presented to the user is not acurate :) This example is based on my own S/MIME certificate which validation path ends up in trusted root certificate (comertial one).

If I open a message which I have sent a year ago it shows the information I have enclosed. At the time of message creation, siganture validation information was positive. Now, it says that certificate is not trusted, which is misleading (certificate just expired).
creator: mn.szczesny

content:
At the time of message creation, siganture validation information was positive. Now, it says that certificate is not trusted, which is misleading (certificate just expired).

I'd agree that the error message is somewhat misleading if this is about your own personal cert, since it complains about an untrusted ca cert in the certificate chain.

I assume that Thunderbird validates certificate only against current date.

If the message was signed when all certificates were valid, and the client supports validation as of the signing date (using trusted timestamping), then the signature may still be considered valid even if certificates have since expired. Most standard email clients do not implement this by default; they typically check certificate validity against the current date, not the signing date, unless a trusted timestamp is present.

Thunderbird does not currently support trusted timestamps (RFC 3161) for S/MIME certificate validation. According to a bug report and feature request, Thunderbird does not recognize or verify RFC 3161 timestamps in S/MIME messages. The expected behavior—validating signatures based on a trusted timestamp if present—is not implemented. Thunderbird only checks certificate validity against the current system date, not the signing time recorded by a timestamp authority.

See also https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=482799 and https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1912613

For any follow-up questions I'd suggest you subscribe to the Topicbox Thunderbird e2ee mailing list at https://thunderbird.topicbox.com/groups/e2ee and ask there.
creator: christ1

content:
You must have separate smtp servers for each account, and set each account to send on the smtp that shares the same User Name, e.g. account A sends on smtp A, account B sends on smtp B, etc.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593
creator: sfhowes

content: You can't enter the gmail account password in Settings. Change the authentication to OAuth2, for incoming and outgoing, remove all entries from Saved Passwords, accept cookies in TB (not browser) Settings, restart TB, enter the account password in the OAuth window, which will store an oauth:// token in Saved Passwords.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thanks for the reply. I still cannot send. I'm using TB 128.11.1esr (64-bit). I was already using OAuth2 and always using imap.gmail.com. There isn't option to set Incoming Outgoing separately. I followed your suggestion to remove those two other OAuth entries in Password list relating to Gmail access. I restarted TB and it opened the Google access window which I OKed TB to read and access my mail. The app went back into TB app so it appears I'm still able to download emails. I then did a test to send new e-mail. it opened the Google access window (again) which I OKed TB to read and access my mail. Then it gave me that same window of those 3 options "Retry, Enter New Password or Cancel". ....until I eventually get the time out window: Sending of the message failed. Unable to authenticate to Outgoing server (SMTP) smtp.gmail.com. Please check the password and verify the 'Authentication method' in 'Account Settings | Outgoing server (SMTP)'.

I'm using IMAP so not sure why the error message is saying SMTP. I now have two OAuth entries in Passwords. I can receive e-mail but cannot send.

Thanks.
creator: dannychung99

content: Open Account Settings, then Outgoing Server (SMTP) at the bottom of the left pane. Select the gmail smtp, Edit..., use smtp.gmail.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address. The outgoing server uses the same oauth:// token as the incoming, as long as you have the account sending on the correct smtp (select the account in the left pane of Account Settings, set the server in the Outgoing Server (SMTP) dropdown in the right pane).
creator: sfhowes

content:
All those settings are what I already have.

I did some more checks and tests. I noticed the error message had an extra m in ...@gmail.comm. I found this in the Outgoing Server email name (which I swear I never touched this field today during password change). I removed the extra m and I'm now able to send out emails. Never actually asked me for the new password.

Thanks for your help.
creator: dannychung99
